sen.j: タカミムスビは、日本神話の神。
sen.e: Takamimusubi is one of the gods who appear in the Japanese mythology.
Takamimusubi is one of the gods who appear in Japanese mythology.
Takamimusubi is one of the gods who appear in Japanese mythology.

sen.j: 古事記では高御産巣日神（タカミムスビノカミ）、日本書紀では高皇産霊神（タカミムスビノカミ）と書かれる。
sen.e: It is written as 高御産巣日神 in "Kojiki" (the Records of Ancient Matters), and as 高皇産霊神 in "Nihon Shoki" (the Chronicles of Japan).
It is written as 高御産巣日神 in "Kojiki" (the Records of Ancient Matters), and as 高皇産霊神 in "Nihon Shoki" (the Chronicles of Japan).
It is written as 高御産巣日神 in "Kojiki" (the Records of Ancient Matters), and as 高皇産霊神 in "Nihonshoki" (the Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 葦原中津国平定・天孫降臨の際には高木神（タカギノカミ）という名で登場する。
sen.e: This kami appears under the name of Takaginokami (高木神) at the time of the pacification of Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (the Central Land of the Reed Plain, which is the land between the heaven and the land of the dead, i.e. the earth) and tenson-korin (天孫降臨: the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess).

This kami appears under the name of Takaginokami (高木神) at the time of the pacification of Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (the Central Land of the Reed Plain, which is the land between heaven and the land of the dead, i.e. the earth) and tenson-korin (天孫降臨: the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess).

This kami appears under the name of Takaginokami at the time of the pacification of Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (the Central Land of the Reed Plain, which is the land between heaven and the land of the dead, i.e. the earth) and tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess).
sen.cmt: 漢字表記を一部削除しました。

sen.j: 神社の祭神としては高皇産霊尊（タカミムスビノミコト）などとも書かれる。
sen.e: The name can also be written as 高皇産霊尊 (Takamimusubi no Mikoto) as an enshrined deity.
The name can also be written as 高皇産霊尊 (Takamimusubi no Mikoto) as an enshrined deity.
The name can also be written as 高皇産霊尊 (Takamimusubi no Mikoto) as an enshrined deity.

sen.j: 天照大神の御子神・アメノオシホミミが高皇産霊神（タカミムスビノカミ）の娘と結婚して生まれたのが天孫ニニギノミコトであるので、タカミムスビは天孫ニニギの外祖父に相当する。
sen.e: As Tenson Ninigi no Mikoto, the grandson of Amaterasu-Omikami (天照大神: the sun goddess) was born by the marriage of Amenooshihomimi (son of Amaterasu) and a daughter of Takamimusubi no Kami, Takamimusubi is equivalent to Tenson Ninigi's maternal grandfather.

As Tenson Ninigi no Mikoto, the grandson of Amaterasu-Omikami (天照大神: the sun goddess) was born by the marriage of Amenooshihomimi (son of Amaterasu) and a daughter of Takamimusubi no Kami, Takamimusubi is equivalent to Tenson Ninigi's maternal grandfather.

As Tenson Ninigi no Mikoto, the grandson of Amaterasu Omikami (the sun goddess) was born by the marriage of Amenooshihomimi (son of Amaterasu) and a daughter of Takamimusubi no Kami, Takamimusubi is equivalent to Tenson Ninigi's maternal grandfather.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記を一部削除しました。

sen.j: 古事記によれば、天地開闢 (日本神話)の時、最初に天御中主神が現れ、その次にカミムスビと共に高天原に出現したとされるのが高皇産霊神という神である。
sen.e: According to Kojiki, Ame no Minakanushi no Kami first came into being in Takamagahara (the Plain of High Heaven) at the time of the creation of heaven and earth (Japanese mythology), and then appeared Takamimusubi no Kami together with another kami called Kamimusubi.

According to Kojiki, Ame no Minakanushi no Kami first came into being in Takamagahara (the Plain of High Heaven) at the time of the creation of heaven and earth (Japanese mythology), and then appeared Takamimusubi no Kami together with another kami called Kamimusubi.

According to Kojiki, Ame no Minakanushi no Kami first came into being in Takamagahara (the Plain of High Heaven) at the time of the creation of heaven and earth (Japanese mythology), and then appeared Takamimusubi no Kami together with another kami called Kamimusubi.

sen.j: 天御中主神・神皇産霊神・高皇産霊神は、共に造化の三神とされ、いずれも性別のない神、かつ、人間界から姿を隠している「独神（ひとりがみ）」とされている。
sen.e: Ame no Minakanushi no Kami, Kamimusubi no Kami and Takamimusubi no Kami are collectively called "Zoka-sanshin" (three kami of creation), who are said to be genderless "hitorigami (solitary kami) hiding their figures from the world of human beings.

Ame no Minakanushi no Kami, Kamimusubi no Kami and Takamimusubi no Kami are collectively called "Zoka-sanshin" (three kami of creation), who are said to be genderless "hitorigami (solitary kami) hiding their figures from the world of human beings.

Ame no Minakanushi no Kami, Kamimusubi no Kami and Takamimusubi no Kami are collectively called "Zoka-sanshin" (three gods of creation), who are said to be genderless 'hitorigami' (god without gender) hiding their figures from the world of human beings.
sen.cmt: " → ' としました。独神→hitorigami (god without gender) としました。

sen.j: この造化三神のうち、神皇産霊神・高皇産霊神は、その活動が皇室・朝廷に直接的に大いに関係していると考えられたため、神祇官八神として八神殿で祀られた。
sen.e: Of the three kami of Zoka-sanshin, Kamimusubi no Kami and Takamimusubi no Kami were worshipped in the Hasshinden (eight shrines) of Jingikan (department of worship under the Ritsuryo system - a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryō codes) as their activities were considered to have been directly and heavily related to the Imperial Household and the Imperial Court.

Of the three kami of Zoka-sanshin, Kamimusubi no Kami and Takamimusubi no Kami were worshipped in the Hasshinden (eight shrines) of Jingikan (department of worship under the Ritsuryo system - a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryō codes) as their activities were considered to have been directly and heavily related to the Imperial Household and the Imperial Court.

Of the three kami of Zoka-sanshin, Kamimusubi no Kami and Takamimusubi no Kami were worshipped in the Hasshinden (eight shrines) of Jingikan (department of worship under the Ritsuryo system - a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryō codes) as their activities were considered to have been directly and heavily related to the Imperial Household and the Imperial Court.

sen.j: タカミムスビは、日本書紀では、天地初発条一書第四に「又曰く～」という形式で登場しているに過ぎない神であり、その他では巻十五の顕宗紀において阿閇臣事代が任那に派遣され壱岐及び対馬に立ち寄った際に名前が登場する程度ではある。
sen.e: In Nihon Shoki, Takamimusubi is a god who merely appears in the fourth alternate writing (which begins as "Also it is said...") in Section 1 which covers the beginning of heaven and earth, and in Chapter 15 'Kenzo-ki' (Records of Kenzo Period), wherein its name appears in an episode of Abe no omi no kotoshiro (a representative of Abe clan in present-day Ueno, Iga City, Mie Prefecture) making a stopover at the islands of Iki and Tsushima when he was dispatched to Mimana (countries in the southern Korean Peninsula).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処 （’あるが’を’ある。’に変更しました）Section 1のあとにChapter 1を入れるといいと思いますが、原文にないので遠慮しました。阿閇臣事代、任那にそれぞれ説明を付与しました。
sen.e: In Nihon Shoki, Takamimusubi is a god who merely appears in the fourth alternate writing (which begins as "Also it is said...") in Section 1 which covers the beginning of heaven and earth, and in Chapter 15 'Kenzo-ki' (Records of Kenzo Period), wherein its name appears in an episode of Abe no omi no kotoshiro (a representative of Abe clan in present-day Ueno, Iga City, Mie Prefecture) making a stopover at the islands of Iki and Tsushima when he was dispatched to Mimana (countries in the southern Korean Peninsula).

In Nihonshoki, Takamimusubi is a god who merely appears in the Arufumi (supplement volumes of explanatory notes in Nihonshoki) Vol. 4 which covers the beginning of heaven and earth, and in Chapter 15 "Kenzo-ki" (Records of Kenzo period), wherein its name appears in an episode of Abe no omi no kotoshiro (a representative of Abe clan in present-day Ueno, Iga City, Mie Prefecture) making a stopover at the islands of Iki and Tsushima when he was dispatched to Mimana (countries in the southern Korean Peninsula).
sen.cmt: 日本書紀の一書 の表現を統一しました。

sen.j: しかし、天孫降臨神話では天照大神より優位に立って天孫降臨を司令している伝が存在することから、この神が本来の皇祖神だとする説もある。
sen.e: But there is also a view that Takamimusubi is the primary god from whom the Imperial Family is believed to be descended based on a legend existing in the tenson-korin related mythology that he was in full control of tenson-korin, gaining ascendancy over Amaterasu Omikami
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処 （’が’を’しかし’に変更しました）
sen.e: But there is also a view that Takamimusubi is the primary god from whom the Imperial Family is believed to be descended based on a legend existing in the tenson-korin related mythology that he was in full control of tenson-korin, gaining ascendancy over Amaterasu Omikami

But there is also a view that Takamimusubi is the primary god from whom the Imperial Family is believed to be descended based on a legend existing in the tensonkorin related mythology that he was in full control of tensonkorin, gaining ascendancy over Amaterasu Omikami
sen.cmt: tensonkorin としてハイフンを削除して統一しました。

sen.j: また、延喜式祝詞・出雲国神賀詞には、「神王タカミムスビ」とされている。
sen.e: In addition, he is referred to as 'kamumioya (神王: divine ancestor) Takamimusubi' in Izumo no Kuni Kamuyogoto (auspicious words presented to the emperor by a newly assigned regional official in charge of Izumo Province), which is one of the "norito" (祝詞: liturgy) quoted in "Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers).
sen.cmt: 原文にある「神王」の読みが賀茂真淵、本居宣長、平田篤胤など人によって異なり（それぞれ’カブロギ’、’カムロギ’、’カブロ’）迷うところですが、ここでは次田潤（うるう）（故）という元学習院教授が自著「祝詞新講」で主張されている「カムミオヤ（意味は祖神、あるいは神祖」という見解を採用しています。
sen.e: In addition, he is referred to as 'kamumioya (神王: divine ancestor) Takamimusubi' in Izumo no Kuni Kamuyogoto (auspicious words presented to the emperor by a newly assigned regional official in charge of Izumo Province), which is one of the "norito" (祝詞: liturgy) quoted in "Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers).

In addition, he is referred to as 'kamumioya (神王: divine ancestor) Takamimusubi' in Izumo no Kuni Kamuyogoto (auspicious words presented to the emperor by a newly assigned regional official in charge of Izumo Province), which is one of the "norito" (祝詞: liturgy) quoted in "Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers).

sen.j: 神皇産霊神は出雲神話で、高皇産霊神は高天原神話で働くという。
sen.e: It is said that Kamimusubi no Kami is active in the Izumo mythology and Takamimusubi no Kami in the Takamagahara mythology.
sen.cmt: 「働く」の意味が明瞭でなく、「活発である」というように解釈しました。ただその場合でも「～という」という伝聞形の表現が気になります。原文著者の意向が確認できればと思います。
sen.e: It is said that Kamimusubi no Kami is active in the Izumo mythology and Takamimusubi no Kami in the Takamagahara mythology.
It is said that Kamimusubi no Kami is active in the Izumo mythology and Takamimusubi no Kami in the Takamagahara mythology.

sen.j: 天津国玉神の子であるアメノワカヒコが、天孫降臨に先立って降ったが復命せず、問責の使者・雉（きぎし）の鳴女（なきめ）を射殺した。
sen.e: Ame no Wakahiko, a child of Amatsukunitama no Kami, was ordered to descend to earth prior to tenson-korin, but he sent no report on his mission to the Plain of High Heaven, and moreover, he killed with an arrow Kigishi no Nakime (a pheasant) who was dispatched to reprimand him.

Ame no Wakahiko, a child of Amatsukunitama no Kami, was ordered to descend to earth prior to tenson-korin, but he sent no report on his mission to the Plain of High Heaven, and moreover, he killed with an arrow Kigishi no Nakime (a pheasant) who was dispatched to reprimand him.

Ame no Wakahiko, a child of Amatsukunitama no Kami, was ordered to descend to earth prior to tensonkorin, but he sent no report on his mission to the Plain of High Heaven, and moreover, he killed with an arrow Kigishi no Nakime (a pheasant) who was dispatched to reprimand him.
sen.cmt: tensonkorin としてハイフンを削除して統一しました。

sen.j: それが高皇産霊神の怒りに触れ、その矢を射返されて死んだという。
sen.e: It gave such offence to Takamimusubi no Kami who then shot back the same arrow and killed Ame no Wakahiko.
It gave such offence to Takamimusubi no Kami who then shot back the same arrow and killed Ame no Wakahiko.
It gave such offence to Takamimusubi no Kami who then shot back the same arrow and killed Ame no Wakahiko.

sen.j: 「むすひ」は生産・生成を意味する言葉で、神皇産霊神とともに「創造」を神格化した神であり、女神的要素を持つ神皇産霊神と対になって男女の「むすび」を象徴する神であるとも考えられる。
sen.e: "Musuhi" is a word which means production or formation, which leads to a possible interpretation that Takamimusubi no Kami and Kamimusubi no Kami are the deification of "creation", and that this couple, along with the goddess factor held by Kamimusubi no Kami, symbolizes "musubi" (uniting) of man and woman.

"Musuhi" is a word which means production or formation, which leads to a possible interpretation that Takamimusubi no Kami and Kamimusubi no Kami are the deification of "creation", and that this couple, along with the goddess factor held by Kamimusubi no Kami, symbolizes "musubi" (uniting) of man and woman.

The word 'Musuhi' means production or formation, which leads to a possible interpretation that Takamimusubi no Kami and Kamimusubi no Kami are the deification of 'creation,' and that this couple, along with the goddess factor held by Kamimusubi no Kami, symbolizes 'musubi' (uniting) of man and woman.

sen.j: 子にオモイカネ、栲幡千千姫命がいる。
sen.e: Omoikane and Takuhatachijihime no Mikoto are the children of Takamimusubi no Kami.
Omoikane and Takuhatachijihime no Mikoto are the children of Takamimusubi no Kami.
Omoikane and Takuhatachijihime no Mikoto are the children of Takamimusubi no Kami.
